page.title: 13DOMESDAY ARNCLIFFE
page.content: Arncliffe gets its name from the Saxon word meaning "eagle" or "falcon". In the time of the Domesday Book, Arncliffe was referred to as Arneclif or Erneclive. The original settlement was probably Danish, though there may have been an even earlier settlement, of which there is now no trace or record. After the Norman conquest, the land was held by Roger Le Poitevin. His land in Arncliffe was held by a man called Torfin, who had 4 carucates of land. This is equivalent to about 400 acres. Roger Le Poitevin did not have the land for long. There is some doubt as to the exact reason for his losing favour with King William, but his lands were passed into the hands of the Percy family, who held them for many years.
